comments.author: James Cobalt

comments.text:
The butterflies are symbolic but not of Yenny. In the lyrics she says her 
boyfriend is attracted to pretty girls like a butterfly is attracted to 
colors. Breaking the container the butterfly is in as she begins walking to 
her boyfriend is symbolic that she's going to break their bonds too- 
letting him go.

That same line about colors is significant too. You'll notice the entire 
video was shot in a neutral palette- that is until we get to the the pretty 
thing the butterfly is attracted to. She sits in front of a bright red wall.

When they leave in the cab we are back to neutral colors. The cab's roof ad 
features the question going through Yenny's mind right as it drives by her. 
We don't see color again until that deep red returns in her boyfriend's 
apartment (literally shining out through the open doorway)- implying he's 
there with the girl. 

My interpretation of the final shots is that as she stands in the door 
discovering her boyfriend's indiscretions she realizes she too was just 
another pretty thing he was attracted to. The butterfly coming out of his 
apartment and landing on her being symbolic of that realization.

The 2nd to last shot is especially arresting. On one side we have the blue 
butterfly and a blue background i.e. boyfriend. On the other side we have 
red lighting and a red background i.e. the other woman. Yenny finds herself 
smack dab in the middle of this scene.

As the camera pans out we see her bathed in the color red. I suppose this 
could be further read as her not being any different from the new girl he 
brought home, or of her anger, or that she is completely done with the 
boyfriend (no more blue in the shot). Or you know, all or none of the above.
comments.author: James Cobalt

Yup. The dancing part (all parts) actually symbolize her feelings of 
confusion and desperation. It's like.. she wants to go and find out the 
truth, but at tje same time she hesitates and stops herself from moving 
forward. The butterfly symbolizes herself. It's like she was caught up in a 
web (the butterfly was in a jar in the beginning) then she stumbled on it 
and it flew freely. That's her being able to free herself from the 
depression of loving and longing for her lover so she searched him herself. 
The ending part when the butterfly rested on her shoulder, it was like she 
has become whole and finally found out the truth.

This MV is art and poetry at its fnest and it's sad that a lot of people 
don't get the point.

comments.text:
From what I've heard she pronounces it "Hotfelt". Which is a little 
misleading because I would assume it was pronounced like heartfelt is 
pronounced only without the /r/ sound. 

Compare the American Way of saying heartfelt: /ˈhɑ:rt.fɛlt/ versus the 
British way: /ˈhɑ:t.fɛlt/. The ":" calls for a long vowel, only when she 
pronounced it, it sounded more like /hɑt,fɛlt/. 

Personally I'm gonna pronounce it "haatfelt" with an extra long "a", but I 
guess the "true" pronunciation is whatever She dictates. (sorry for the 
lesson in phonetics, :P I just wanted to be as clear with what I mean as 
possible)

top_comment.text:
For the people who say this is ok-ish, or mediocre, I am totally judging 
you. I can understand hating on hyuna, or sistar or in general every song 
released this year, but this is pure epicness. The song is a masterpiece. 
It is something the kpop world really needs. Yenny (and i wasn't even a fan 
before this), step up the game and she released what i can say is the best 
song of the year....

She pulled an adele if you ask me, she sat down and put all her pain in one 
song, that shows a person's heart being crushed in every way possible. The 
sad and slow part shows pain and hurt, while the dubstep which still has 
the sad feeling explains the part where you just want to scream, destroy or 
break everything, and cry and really feel like breaking down, when you just 
need someone to hug you, and be there. I love how her voice breaks just 
before the chorus, and shows she is ready to break down, but then her voice 
becomes powerful while she tries to show him that she loves him through 
that. Amazing... AMAZING!!!

I am very sad the song isn't slaying as much as it should, i was expecting 
total slayage considering sunmi's solo debut was successful, and even 
netizens realised how good it is. Sad times for kpop if this song goes 
unnoticed.

I am very happy i met you through your music Yenny, i feel the need to hug 
you every time i listen to your songs. Keep producing awesome songs like 
this for you and for everyone in JYP since you are the best producer they 
got it seems (since miss a get stupid mediocre-at-best songs).﻿
top_comment.author: MrTwilighter

comments.text:
YES! The choreographer and director were clearly influenced by Maddie 
Ziegler's dancing in Sia's Chandelier video. The lamp and heroin-chic 
expressionless face gave it away from the start. Unfortunately, the self 
loathing and destructive mania conveyed in that dance arrangement were 
completely inappropriate for Park's song.

Ain't Nobody is a powerful piece and Park nails it. The narrative is about 
being emotionally ripped to shreds, yet rising to a new level of maturity. 
The woman in the song's lyrics is not falling apart at all. She has 
recognized an inner strength that she deserves to be loved as deeply as she 
loves her partner, who is an immature boy. He is the fool who doesn't 
recognize that no one will love him like she does. The whole song is 
rhetorical.

Sia's song is about a woman filling her emptiness and low self esteem with 
alcohol, sex, and probably self-inflicted injuries. The woman in Sia's song 
wants to be used and abused because she wants to die.

Park's song is about a woman who despite being crushed, still stands 
triumphant and reflects on her relationship. The director and choreographer 
were idiots.
comments.author: Elephant Topic

WOW. I was checking the new Kpop MV's and I don't fall for new musics 
easily ... I don't like mainstream boy groups (EXO, Teen Top, BEAST or

talents, and they are a few.

discovery for me.﻿

I didn't come to spit on other fandoms and criticize the bands I don't like.
I just read a comm which explains really well what I'm thinking about all 
this matter.
Speaking of new Rap Monster's MV (member of BTS), LillysLookForLess said :
 
"I've said it before but I'll say it again... I give MAJOR respect to 
BigHit for allowing Rapmonster (AND SUGA) to compose and produce their own 
songs. I feel like a lot of people who become "idols" are restricted to 
pursue their passion in music because of reputation and all. Which is sad 
because that pretty much kills the idol's passion and love for music. Too 
many Kpop Entertainment restrict and sucks out the passion from most Idols. 
"

I've listened to almost every new kpop idol group (I've been following kpop 
since 2011) and I've seen the creation of a lot of new epic groups. I was 
one of the fans who watched every single EXO's teaser and tried to learn 
their names before their debut. But then ... I was pretty disappointed.
I think it's a matter of taste, I just can't appreciate the whole thing. I 
get bored really quickly, and this made me search for those "real talents" 
I spoke about. Here again, it is a subjective point of view. Yes, some 
idols have good voices. But they can't really create their art because 
their agencies restrict them.
That's why I really love underground music, kpop hip hop and the artists 
who are not that famous. Because they are still free.

Sorry if it was difficult to understand, I'm still learning english ;)
